data.title: Pete Wentz Watched Metallica Doc Before Making Fall Out Boy Album
meta_keywords: how fall out boy got inspired by metallica documentary
how some kind of monster inspired fall out boy
data.meta_description: Metallica and Fall Out Boy are closer than you think.
data.text:
Fall Out Boy's Pete Wentz recently explained how Metallica's Some Kind of Monster helped him put focus on his long-running pop-punk band, particularly when considering musical longevity.

The Fall Out Boy bassist and figurehead (pictured above at left) watched the 2004 Metallica documentary ahead of recording his group's eighth studio album, the forthcoming So Much (for) Stardust.

Metallica: Some Kind of Monster shines a light on the sometimes tense recording of the metal band's 2003 album, St. Anger, and goes behind the scenes on the addition of now-longtime Metallica bassist Robert Trujillo after Jason Newsted's departure.

Today, it offers a unique look at a veteran band still on the climb. It seems that's what Wentz took from it.

"Before we started working on the [new] record, I was watching Some Kind of Monster," Wentz tells Zane Lowe on Apple Music 1. "Somehow in my head, I always thought that they were a band for 30 or 40 years." (Fall Out Boy formed in 2001, Metallica in 1981.)

He continues, "I don't really know why but I was like, oh, we've been a band the same length that they were a band when they shot this, which is just a really weird mirror to look into."

Apparently, other members of Fall Out Boy also watched Some Kind of Monster, or at least spoke with Wentz about the metal doc. That includes lead singer and guitarist Patrick Stump (pictured above, center).

"Because what you were saying, the thing about, 'Do they get along?'" Stump adds to Wentz's thought. "There's so many things that have to line up for a band to make a record at this point, let alone a good one."

On Wednesday (Jan. 18), Fall Out Boy released the first single from So Much (for) Stardust, "Love From the Other Side." They've issued a hits compilation and an EP since their last album, 2017's M A N I A.

So Much (for) Stardust arrives March 24.
